revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Traditional gentlemen's clubs in the United States‎ to [[:Category:Gentlemen's clubs in the United States‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2018_May_1]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = University Club of Washington, D.C. | logo = | type= [[Gentlemen's club|Private club]] | image = University Club.JPG | foundation = 1904 | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | services = Hotel, Dining, Athletics, Meetings | homepage = [http://www.universityclubdc.com www.universityclubdc.com] }}
The '''University Club of Washington, D.C.''', is an American [[gentlemen's club|private club]] in [[Downtown (Washington, D.C.)|downtown]] [[Washington, D.C.]], United States.
==History==
Established in 1904 simply as the University Club, its first president was then Secretary of War and future United States President [[William Howard Taft]]. In 1936, it merged with the '''Racquet Club of Washington''', and moved to its current location at 1135 Sixteenth Street NW, approximately three blocks north of the [[White House]].<ref name="universityclubdc">{{cite web|url=http://www.universityclubdc.com/Default.aspx?p=DynamicModule&pageid=240299 |title=History - University Club of Washington DC |publisher=Universityclubdc.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref>
During the [[Warren Court]] justices [[Earl Warren]] and [[Hugo Black]] would often use the Club's facilities to informally discuss and gather.<ref name="universityclubdc" />
==Reciprocity== The Club has reciprocal agreements for its members with approximately 200 other athletic, country, and city clubs around the United States and the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universityclubdc.com/Default.aspx?p=DynamicModule&pageid=240307 |title=Reciprocal Clubs - University Club of Washington DC |publisher=Universityclubdc.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref>
==Athletics== The Club contains a health and fitness center including two international [[squash (sport)|squash]] courts where it hosts the annual Mosquito Open.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalcapitalsquash.org/mosquito-open-july-13-15-deadline-july-9/ |title=Mosquito Open July 13-15, deadline — July 9 | National Capital Squash |publisher=Nationalcapitalsquash.org |date=2012-05-28 |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref> The [[Tewaaraton Trophy|Tewaaraton Award]] was founded at the Club in 2000 and is presented annually to the [[NCAA]] [[Lacrosse]] player of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tewaaraton.com/ |title=Tewaaraton Award |publisher=Tewaaraton.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref> It is the lacrosse equivalent of football's [[Heisman Trophy]]. The trophy is presented jointly by The Tewaaraton Foundation and the University Club of Washington, D.C.. One trophy is presented to the top men's player, and one trophy is presented to the top women's player each year.
==Notable members== Notable past and current Club members include former Speaker of the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] [[Tip O'Neill]],<ref name="universityclubdc" /> former [[President of the United States|President]] [[Richard Nixon]],<ref name="bare_url">{{cite web|url=http://news.muckety.com/2008/10/07/federal-judges-will-have-to-pay-for-golf-like-everyone-else/5571 |title=Supreme Court justices lose freebie memberships | Muckety - See the news |publisher=News.muckety.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref> numerous [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] Justices,<ref name="bare_url" /> former [[United States Secretary of Homeland Security|Homeland Security Secretary]] [[Tom Ridge]], and former [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Donald Rumsfeld]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Zakheim |first=Roger I. |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/article/129278#.UCftc2Oe7gI |title=Rummy is a University man |publisher=WashingtonExaminer.com |date=2007-11-13 |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of American gentlemen's clubs]] * [[Cosmos Club]] * [[Metropolitan Club (Washington, D.C.)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|University Club}} *[http://www.universityclubdc.com University Club of Washington, DC]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Romani people and Romanipen in Romania]] to [[Category:Romani in Romania]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 11]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{For|the village in [[Călăraşi district]], [[Moldova]]|Buda, Călăraşi}} [[File:Theodor_Aman_-_Ursarul.jpg|thumb|320px|''The Ursar'', drawing by [[Theodor Aman]]]] {{Romani people}} The '''Ursari''' (generally read as "bear leaders" or "bear handlers"; from the [[Romanian language|Romanian]] ''urs'', meaning "bear"; singular: ''ursar''; [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]]: урсари, ''ursari'') or '''Richinara''' are the traditionally [[nomad]]ic occupational group of [[Animal training|animal trainers]] among the [[Romani people]].
An [[Endogamy|endogamous]] category originally drawing the bulk of its income from [[busking]] performances in which they used [[dancing bear]]s, usually [[brown bear]]s and, in several instances, [[Old World monkey|Old world monkeys]], they have largely become settled after the 1850s. The Ursari form an important part of the [[Roma minority in Romania|Roma community]] in [[Romania]], where they are one of the 40 tribal groups,<ref name="romiiromania">{{ro icon}} Centrul de Documentare şi Informare despre Minorităţile din Europa de Sud-Est, [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/html/cim_pdf452.pdf ''Romii din România''], at the [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/ Erdélyi Magyar Adatbank], retrieved June 25, 2007</ref> as well as notable segments of the [[Bulgaria]]n [[Roma in Bulgaria|Roma population]] and of the one in [[Moldova]]. They also form a sizable part of the Roma present in [[Serbia]] and [[Western Europe]]an countries such as the [[Netherlands]] and [[Italy]].
The word ''Ursari'' may also refer to a [[dialect]] of [[Balkan Romani language|Balkan Romani]], as spoken in Romania and Moldova,<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=rmn ''Balkan Romani'' at Ethnologue.com], retrieved June 23, 2007</ref><ref name="rombaseethgroup">[http://romani.uni-graz.at/rombase/ "Roma – Sub Ethnic Groups", at Rombase], retrieved June 23, 2007</ref> although it is estimated that most Ursari, like the [[Boyash]], speak Romanian as their native language.<ref name="angusfraser">Angus M. Fraser, ''The Gypsies'', [[Blackwell Publishing]], [[Oxford]], 1995, p.45-48, 226. {{ISBN|0-631-19605-6}}</ref> There is no scholarly consensus on whether Ursari belong to the [[Sinti]] subgroup of the Roma people or to the other half of the Roma population.<ref>Lucassen, p.84, 86, 90</ref> A Romanian poll conducted in 2004 among 347 Roma found that 150 referred to themselves as "Ursari" (or 43.2%, and the largest single group).<ref name="surduunicef">{{ro icon}} Mihai Surdu, [http://www.unicef.org/romania/ro/Roma_Girls_Early_Marriage.pdf ''Sarcina şi căsătoria timpurie în cazul tinerelor roma''], at [[UNICEF]] Romania, retrieved June 24, 2007</ref>
The Romanian-speaking Roma bear or monkey handlers in Bulgaria, called ''mechkari'' (мечкари), ''maymunari'', or ''ursari'', are occasionally seen as a separate community<ref name="rombaseethgroup"/> or as a distinct part of the Boyash population,<ref name="patrin">Elena Marushiakova, Vesselin Popov, [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/~Patrin/bulg-structre.htm&date=2009-10-26+00:36:49 "Ethnosocial Structure of the Roma of Bulgaria"], in [https://web.archive.org/web/20080213171929/http://www.geocities.com/~Patrin/ ''The Patrin Web Journal: Romani Culture and History''], retrieved June 24, 2007</ref> as are persons identified as Ursari in Italy.<ref name="pijatsromano">{{it icon}} [http://www.cesv.org/media/7248/pijats%20romano.pdf ''Scheda progetto per l'impiego di volontari in Servizio Civile in Italia. Pijats Romanò''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926101658/http://www.cesv.org/media/7248/pijats%20romano.pdf |date=2007-09-26 }}, at the [http://www.cesv.org/ Centro Servizi per il Volontariato], retrieved June 24, 2007</ref> The ''Coşniţari'' (or ''koshnichari'') group, present on both sides of the [[Danube]] (in both Romania and Bulgaria), is believed to be a segment of the Ursari.<ref name="grigoreantrop">{{ro icon}} [[Delia Grigore]], [http://www.romanothan.ro/romana/studii/minoritati/curs_antropologie.htm ''Curs de antropologie şi folclor rrom''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423232321/http://www.romanothan.ro/romana/studii/minoritati/curs_antropologie.htm |date=2008-04-23 }}, hosted by [[Romanothan]], retrieved June 24, 2007</ref> Other such [[Eastern Europe]]an groups, although linked by profession, speak different languages and dialects, and are not considered part of the Ursari; they include the ''Medvedara'' in [[Greece]], ''Ričkara'' in [[Slovakia]], and ''Roma Ayjides'' in the [[Istanbul]] area of [[Turkey]].<ref name="rombaseethgroup"/><ref name="rombasecarneys">[http://romani.uni-graz.at/rombase/ "Carneys and Street Artists", at Rombase], retrieved June 23, 2007</ref>
==History== {{Main|Roma minority in Romania|Roma in Bulgaria}}
===Early migrations and slavery=== [[File:Tanzbär 1810.jpg|thumb|320px|Print showing of a dancing bear and its handlers in [[Hesse]], ca. 1810]] Groups of bear-handlers are known to have existed during the population's transit through the [[Byzantine Empire]], as early as the 12th century, when they are mentioned in connection with the ''[[Melchisedechians|Athinganoi]]'' (Roma people) by [[Theodore Balsamon]].<ref name="angusfraser"/> In later decades, they were probably among the people collectively referred to as "[[Egyptians (Balkans)|Egyptians]]".<ref name="angusfraser"/>
The Ursari formed part of the [[Slavery|slave]] population in the [[Danubian Principalities]] ([[Moldavia]] and [[Wallachia]]) before the [[Abolitionism|abolitions]] of the 1840s and 1850s. With the Boyash (including the gold-[[prospecting]] ''Zlătari''), the [[Kalderash]], and groups of Roma [[Smith (metalwork)|smiths]], Ursari formed the category of ''lăieşi'', who, unlike ''vătraşi'' slaves, were allowed to carry on with a nomadic lifestyle (being required by their [[boyar]] masters to pay various benefits in exchange for the permission).<ref name="djuvara">[[Neagu Djuvara]], ''Între Orient şi Occident. Ţările române la începutul epocii moderne'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 1995, p.267-269. {{ISBN|973-28-0523-4}}</ref><ref name="pons">{{ro icon}} Emmanuelle Pons, [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/html/cim_pdf450.pdf ''De la robie la asimilare''], p.18-19, at the [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/ Erdélyi Magyar Adatbank], retrieved June 23, 2007</ref>
By the early decades of the 19th century, most of the state-owned Roma were ''lăieşi'', as opposed to private-owned ones.<ref name="grigoreantrop"/><ref name="djuvara"/><ref name="thouvenel">[[Édouard Antoine Thouvenel]], ''La Hongrie et la Valachie'', Arthus Betrand, Paris, 1840, p.242-243</ref> The ''lăieşi'' were required to contribute an annual sum to the treasuries of Wallachia and Moldavia;<ref name="pons"/><ref name="thouvenel"/> [[Édouard Antoine Thouvenel]], a [[France|French]] diplomat who visited Wallachia during the period, indicated that, for Ursari families, this sum amounted to between twenty and thirty [[Turkish kuruş|piasters]],<ref name="thouvenel"/> and it is documented that the Boyash and the Ursari paid equivalent fees.<ref name="pons"/>
Like other nomadic Roma, Ursari are known to have traveled in large tribal groups during the 20th century,<ref name="sendreazbacau">{{ro icon}} Eugen Şendrea, [http://www.ziaruldebacau.ro/index.php?articol=20889 "Distracţii de tîrgoveţi"], in ''[[Ziarul de Bacău]]'', May 26, 2007; retrieved June 24, 2007</ref> although other sources indicate that they preferred to organize themselves on a tight and selective family-based structure.<ref name="baerlein">Henry Baerlein (ed.), ''Romanian Oasis: A Further Anthology on Romania and Her People'', Frederick Muller Ltd., London, 1948, p.202</ref> Ursari people and the Boyash-proper traditionally accompanied the Kalderash on their travels to [[Rumelia]], contributing to the birth of the ''Mechkara'' community.<ref name="patrin"/>
Thouvenel described the group's "miserable condition", and, in reference to their handling of brown bears, wrote: "[...] they reunite to give chase to [the bears], whom they [[Domestication|domesticate]] after capturing them in their youth, or whom they render unable to harm them. Bears in the [[Carpathian Mountains|Carpathians]] are, after all, much smaller and of a less ferocious nature than those in the [[Nord (French department)|Nord]]; their leaders train them with relative ease and run around from village to village in order to collect a few ''[[Para (currency)|para]]'' as a result of peasant curiosity".<ref name="thouvenel"/>
Also according to Thouvenel, Ursari were known for "[[Veterinary medicine|veterinary]] skills", which, he argued, "the [[superstition]] of people in the countryside attributes to the possession of a [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] art".<ref name="thouvenel"/> In addition to bear handling, the community would occasionally trade in wild animals (specifically bear cubs),<ref name="grigoreantrop"/> and was known for keeping and training monkeys.<ref name="patrin"/><ref>Fonseca, p.181</ref> Female members of the community were known for their practice of [[fortune-telling]].<ref name="sendreazbacau"/><ref name="baerlein"/>
===Emancipation=== [[File:Ursari in Transylvania 1869.jpg|thumb|220px|Ursari in [[Transylvania]], 1869 engraving]] Speaking during the late 1880s, the historian and politician [[Mihail Kogălniceanu]], who was responsible for the 1855 abolition of slavery in Moldavia under [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]] [[Grigore Alexandru Ghica]], claimed that: "aside from the [other] ''lăieşi'' Gypsies, who still live in part in Gypsy camps, and Ursari, who are presently working in the taming of wild beasts, but are nevertheless involved in working the land, almost all of the other classes of Gypsies have blended into the larger mass of the nation, and are only told apart by their swarthy and [[South Asia|Asian]]-like faces and the vividness of their imagination".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Mihail Kogălniceanu]], [http://ro.wikisource.org/wiki/Dezrobirea_%C5%A3iganilor%2C_%C5%9Ftergerea_privilegiilor_boiere%C5%9Fti%2C_emanciparea_%C5%A3%C4%83ranilor ''Dezrobirea ţiganilor, ştergerea privilegiilor boiereşti, emanciparea ţăranilor''] (wikisource)</ref>
Following the creation of a [[Kingdom of Romania|Romanian Principality]], Ursari nonetheless remained a presence associated with [[busking]] and [[fair]]s, especially with those held in [[Bucharest]] and provincial cities such as [[Bacău]].<ref name="sendreazbacau"/><ref name="giurescu">[[Constantin C. Giurescu]], ''Istoria Bucureştilor. Din cele mai vechi timpuri pînă în zilele noastre'', [[Editura Pentru Literatură]], Bucharest, 1966, p.380. {{OCLC|1279610}}</ref> As early as the rule of ''[[Domnitor]]'' [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]], they formed a staple of such spectacles, alongside the music-playing ''[[Lăutari]]'', the ''[[Căluşari]]'', and [[freak show]]s.<ref name="giurescu"/> At around the same time, they included a section of ''zavragii'', smiths who worked as [[day labor]]ers.<ref name="grigoreantrop"/> Also during the late 19th century, the Ursari came to be attested in [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russian]]-ruled [[Bessarabia]], where the local population referred to them and to the ''lăieşi'' in general as ''şătraşi'' ("people living on campsites").<ref name="grigoreantrop"/>
Sometime after 1850, groups of Ursari, Kalderash and Lovari, most likely coming from [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] regions and [[Bosnia (region)|Bosnia]], moved westwards, and were mentioned for the first time as present in the [[North Brabant]] and other areas in the [[Netherlands]] (where their descendants still live).<ref>Lucassen, p.81-82, 89</ref><ref>Nikola Rašić, [http://www.kpcgroep.nl/assets/Paragraph/9264/Assets/6810/Downloaden%20(pdf).pdf ''Romanies in Netherlands''], at the [http://www.kpcgroep.nl/ KPC Groep], retrieved June 23, 2007</ref> A similar move originated in [[Serbia]], around [[Kragujevac]], with Boyash and Ursari moving into northern and central [[Italy]].<ref name="pijatsromano"/> In the Netherlands, central authorities reacted vehemently to the presence of Roma, labeling Ursari and the others with the loaded term "Gypsies"; the reaction of local authorities was more calm, and allowed Ursari to blend into Dutch society, even though most members of the latter community intended to settle in other areas.<ref>Lucassen, p.82, 83</ref>
===Before and after the Porajmos=== In time, a significant number of Ursari joined [[circus]]es,<ref name="pijatsromano"/><ref name="rombasecarneys"/> while many others began manufacturing and trading bone objects and leather (as, respectively, ''[[Pieptănari]]'' and ''[[Ciurari]]''), or associating with the ''Lăutari''.<ref name="grigoreantrop"/><ref name="centereducation">[http://www.cedu.ro/programe/improvedu/res/program%20book.pdf ''Improving Education for Roma Children''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926101659/http://www.cedu.ro/programe/improvedu/res/program%20book.pdf |date=2007-09-26 }}, hosted by the [http://www.cedu.ro/despprofen.php Center Education 2000+] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070827025646/http://www.cedu.ro/despprofen.php |date=2007-08-27 }}, retrieved June 23, 2007</ref> The bears were taught to make dancing moves to a [[tambourine]],<ref name="rombasecarneys"/><ref name="giurescu"/><ref name="centereducation"/> or trained to walk upright and perform tricks such as leaning on canes and rolling over.<ref name="rombasecarneys"/><ref name="sendreazbacau"/> The use of iron rods and [[Nose ring (animals)|nose rings]] in the taming process, as well as other such practices, rose attention from [[animal welfare]] advocates, and have been the subject of criticism from as early as the 1920s, when [[Germany]] forbade the Ursari's trade.<ref name="rombasecarneys"/> It has been reported that bear training involved burning the paws of cubs to the rhythm of music.<ref name="fonseca182">Fonseca, p.182</ref>
During the early stages of [[World War II]], as part of the repressive measures ordered by the [[Iron Guard]], the [[List of Romanian Ministers of the Interior|Minister of the Interior]] of the [[National Legionary State|Romanian Legionary Government]], [[Constantin Petrovicescu]], passed an order preventing Ursari from performing with bears in cities, towns, or villages.<ref name="petcut">{{ro icon}} Petre Petcuţ, [http://www.idee.ro/holocaust/pdf/rromilor.pdf ''Samudaripenul (Holocaustul) rromilor în România''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710135029/http://www.idee.ro/holocaust/pdf/rromilor.pdf |date=2007-07-10 }}, at [http://www.idee.ro/ Idee Communication] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206012752/http://www.idee.ro/ |date=2012-02-06 }}, retrieved June 24, 2007</ref> The official explanation for the measure was that such patterns of movement were helping to spread [[typhus]].<ref name="petcut"/> Over the following years, under [[Ion Antonescu]]'s regime, members of the Ursari community were among the Roma people deported to [[Transnistria (World War II)|Transnistria]], as part of [[Holocaust in Romania|Romania's share in the Holocaust]] (''see also [[Romania during World War II]] and [[Porajmos]]'').<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="petcut"/><ref>Fonseca, p.149</ref>
Interdictions on performing with bears were legislated throughout the [[Eastern Bloc]].<ref name="rombasecarneys"/> In [[Communist Romania]], large groups of Ursari performers were prevented from entering cities,<ref name="sendreazbacau"/> and, under both [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]] and [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]], nomadic Roma were subject to settlement policies<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner">{{ro icon}} Margareta Fleşner, Ioaneta Vintileanu, [http://www.edrc.ro/docs/docs/politia/047-094.pdf "Conflictele locale din judeţul Giurgiu şi implicarea forţelor de poliţie"], in Ioaneta Vintileanu, Gábor Ádám, [http://www.edrc.ro/docs/docs/politia/001-018.pdf ''Poliţia şi comunităţile multiculturale din România''], hosted by [http://www.edrc.ro/ Centrul de Resurse pentru Diversitate Etnoculturală], retrieved June 25, 2007</ref><ref name="fonseca150">Fonseca, p.150</ref> (many were reportedly resettled as early as their return from Transnistria).<ref name="fonseca150"/>
===Post-Communism=== [[File:Travellers on horse drawn carriages with a bear on a rural road in Bulgaria.png|thumb|Romas travelling with a chained bear in Bulgaria, 1990]] [[File:Roma boy in bear costume sm.jpg|thumb|Photograph of a boy in a bear costume, [[Budapest]]]] In April–June 1991, following the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|Revolution of 1989]], Ursari in several localities of Romania's [[Giurgiu County]] — [[Bolintin Deal]], [[Ogrezeni]] and [[Bolintin Vale]] — were the target of ethnic violence. Ursari people were chased away, and many of their lodgings were burned to the ground.<ref name="flesner"/><ref>Fonseca, p.148-155</ref> In Bolintin Deal, where the first such actions took place, this came in retaliation for the murder of a Romanian student, Cristian Melinte, by a young Ursar [[Hitchhiking|hitchhiker]] who was later sentenced to 20 years in prison.<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner"/><ref name="barascu">{{ro icon}} Magda Bărăscu, [http://www.euractiv.ro/uniunea-europeana/articles%7CdisplayArticle/articleID_2822/Romii-din-Bolintin-vineaza-fondurile-UE.html "Romii din Bolintin vînează fondurile UE"], in ''[[Evenimentul Zilei]]'', April 20, 2005, hosted by [http://www.euractiv.ro/index.html Euractiv.ro] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622164343/http://www.euractiv.ro/index.html |date=2007-06-22 }}; retrieved June 25, 2007</ref><ref>Fonseca, p.150-151</ref>
The [[arson]]s were carried out by large groups of local inhabitants, who, according to [[United States|American]] author [[Isabel Fonseca]], acted methodically (they are alleged to have cut down the electrical wires leading to each Ursari house, so that the fire would be contained).<ref>Fonseca, p.152</ref> In Ogrezeni, inter-communal violence was caused by the stabbing of a Romanian during a bar fight.<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner"/> In contrast, the violent acts in Bolintin Vale were unprovoked, and probably came as an effect of the Ogrezeni incident.<ref name="flesner"/>
Commentators have attributed these outbursts to the failure of settlement measures,<ref name="flesner"/><ref name="fonseca154">Fonseca, p.154</ref> with the perception that former nomads were among the privileged class during Communist times.<ref name="fonseca154"/> It was reported that many Romanians in Bolintin Deal believed the Ursari were stealing property and even, in Fonseca's account, that they had been organizing [[photo op]]s for Ceauşescu.<ref>Fonseca, p.153-154</ref>
At the same time, criminal acts among the Ursari have been independently reported: among the Roma present in Bolintin Deal, the largely [[Unemployment|unemployed]] Ursari were not fully integrated; it was indicated that houses of non-Ursari Roma were not targeted during the 1991 events, and that, of the 27 criminal files instrumented in Bolintin between 1989 and 1991, 18 implicated Ursari people (with similar ratios in Ogrezeni).<ref name="flesner"/> It was also noted that the Bolintin Deal and Bolintin Vale mobs comprised not only Romanians, but also Roma belonging to traditionally settled communities.<ref name="flesner"/>
[[Romanian Police]] was criticized for its failure to intervene and prevent violence, despite being made aware of the potential for conflict<ref name="flesner"/> — in Bolintin Deal, 22 out of 26 Ursari houses were burned before the [[Jandarmeria Română|Jandarmeria]] and fire service dispersed the mob.<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner"/> However, in Ogrezeni and Bolintin Vale, Police forces were themselves faced with violence from the mob, after allegations that they had vested interest in supporting the Roma community at large;<ref name="flesner"/> in Ogrezeni, 13 or 14 out of 15 Ursari houses were set on fire, and 11 were devastated in Bolintin Vale.<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner"/>
All members of the Ursari community in Bolintin Deal settled in either [[Bucharest]] or [[Giurgiu]], many of them after selling their plots of land; a group attempted to return in May 1991, but was chased away by the locals.<ref name="romiiromania"/><ref name="flesner"/> Reportedly, authorities informed the Ursari that they had better to run away.<ref name="romiiromania"/> By 2005, several Ursari who had taken residence in [[Sector 4 (Bucharest)|Bucharest Sector 4]] requested to be issued [[deed]]s for formerly state-owned land in Bolintin Deal, which was then being allocated to residents; the local authorities denied their request, arguing that ownership of the land in question was still subject to dispute, and indicating that the Ursari could purchase other plots if they chose to do so.<ref name="barascu"/>
Despite measures taken against bear training and busking, these remained popular in countries of the Bloc, and Ursari were a seasonal presence on the [[Bulgarian Black Sea Coast|Black Sea Coast]] under the [[History of Communist Bulgaria|Bulgarian Communist regime]].<ref name="fonseca182"/> Though much rarer, bear leading is still practiced by nomadic groups of Ursari in various areas of Eastern Europe.<ref name="patrin"/><ref name="rombasecarneys"/><ref name="fonseca182"/>
==Culture== {{Main|Roma society and culture}}
===Identity=== The Ursari are among the groups of Roma to practice [[endogamy]], alongside the [[Kalderash]], the [[Lovari (Roma)|Lovari]] and the [[Gabori]];<ref name="patrin"/><ref name="grigoreantrop"/><ref name="centereducation"/> many ''Mechkara'' believe refer to themselves as "[[Vlachs]]" or "[[Romanians]]", and tend to consider themselves distinct from other Roma.<ref name="patrin"/> For the Ursari community at large, the rules upheld specifically prevent sexual contact with the ''[[Gadjo (non-Roma)|gadjo]]'' and favor [[arranged marriage]]s,<ref name="grigoreantrop"/> but seem to have allowed for intermarriage inside the Boyash community at large.<ref name="patrin"/> They are also among the few Roma groups to allow the [[Wedding traditions and customs|marriage of young teenagers]], although this custom is falling out of use.<ref name="surduunicef"/><ref name="grigoreantrop"/><ref name="centereducation"/>
[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] by tradition (belonging to either the [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] or [[Bulgarian Orthodox Church|Bulgarian Orthodox]] churches),<ref name="patrin"/><ref name="centereducation"/> many Ursari are adhering to [[Protestantism|Protestant]] movements such as [[Pentecostalism]].<ref name="centereducation"/> The Ursari in [[Serbia]] and [[Italy]] are members of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]].<ref name="pijatsromano"/> Days of the calendar traditionally upheld as holidays by the Ursari include February 1, the first day of fair seasons, and the [[Eastern Orthodox liturgical calendar|Orthodox Calendar]] [[November 30 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|November 30 feast]] of [[Saint Andrew]] (whom the Ursari people regard as a [[patron saint]]).<ref name="centereducation"/> In the early first decade of the 21st century, the [[New Testament]] was being translated into the Ursari form of the [[Balkan Romani language]].<ref name="rombaseethgroup"/>
===Ursari and bears=== {{further|Dancing bear}} [[File:Bohemian Bear Tamer 01.jpg|thumb|230px|[[Paul Wayland Bartlett]], ''Bohemian Bear Tamer'' (1888 cast)]] As an aspect of their trade, the Ursari have established and encouraged various folk beliefs and customs involving the bear; these include displaying bears in the courtyards of village houses as a means to protect livestock from attack by smaller wild animals, and ''călcătura ursului'' ("the bear step") or ''călcătura lui Moş Martin'' ("Old Boy Martin's step", based on a common nickname for the animal), which involves allowing bears to tread on a person's back (in the belief that it can ensure the fertility of young people or chase away evil spirits).<ref name="grigoreantrop"/><ref name="centereducation"/><ref>''[http://dexonline.ro/search.php?cuv=c%C4%83lc%C3%A1&source=12 călcá]'' in [[Alexandru Ciorănescu]], ''Dicţionarul etimologic român'', [[Universidad de la Laguna]], Tenerife, 1958-1966; retrieved September 11, 2007</ref>
The latter custom was very popular among Romanians, who viewed it as a [[Home remedy|folk remedy]] for [[back pain]]; welcoming Ursari into one's household to perform the task formed part of a string of events leading to the celebration of [[Easter]], or part of customs ushering in [[Christmas]] and the [[New Year's Eve]].<ref name="sendreazbacau"/><ref>{{ro icon}} Costin Anghel, [http://old.jurnalul.ro/articol_47473/vechi_datini_populare.html "Vechi datini populare"], in ''[[Jurnalul Naţional]]'', March 6, 2006; retrieved June 24, 2007</ref>
Among the members of the Ursari community who manufactured objects of bone, it became widespread to treat the material with [[bear fat]], a [[luxury good]] which, they believed, helped make the products in question more durable.<ref name="grigoreantrop"/> The fat was also being sold to Romanians as medicine to combat [[rheumatism]] and [[List of skeletal disorders|skeletal disorders]], together with bear hairs that were a popular [[amulet]].<ref name="sendreazbacau"/>
The practices associated with bear training have again been the focus of [[animal welfare]] groups ever since the 1990s, and were subject to an adverse campaign in ''[[The International Herald Tribune]]''.<ref>Fonseca, p.180</ref> While noting the use of crude methods of training, [[Isabel Fonseca]], who visited the Ursari in places such as [[Bolintin Deal]] and [[Stara Zagora Province]], argued that, as the main bread-winners for Ursari families, bears were also the recipients of care, attention, and proper feeding.<ref name="fonseca182"/>
Several artists have portrayed Romani bear trainers and their animals in their work. Among them are the Romanian painter and graphic artist [[Theodor Aman]] and the [[United States|American]] sculptor [[Paul Wayland Bartlett]] (whose 1888 ''Bohemian Bear Tamer'' [[Bronze sculpture|bronze]] is on display at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in [[New York City]]).
===Music=== {{Main|Romani music}} While, ever since the 1850s, many Ursari musicians have contributed to ''[[Lăutari]]'' culture to the point where they have grown separated from their original environment,<ref name="grigoreantrop"/> traditional Ursari music survived as a separate genre; fused with [[electronic music]], was popularized in early 21st century Romania by the [[Shukar Collective]] project.<ref name="shokarcollect">[http://www.shukar-collective.net/SITE%20FINAL/bios.htm Shukar Collective site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630130229/http://www.shukar-collective.net/SITE%20FINAL/bios.htm |date=2007-06-30 }}, retrieved June 23, 2007</ref>
A chant used by Ursari trainers has passed into Romanian folklore as a [[nursery rhyme]]. It includes the lyrics: {| width="100%" |- valign="top" | Joacă, joacă Moş Martine,<br> Că-ţi dau pâine cu măsline!<ref name="sendreazbacau"/> | Dance, dance Old Boy Martin,<br> And I shall give you bread and olives! | |}
A longer version of it was still being sung by the Ursari in [[Bacău County]] by 2007: {| width="100%" |- valign="top" | Foaie verde pădureţ,<br> Urcă ursule pe băţ,<br> Urcă, urcă tot mai sus,<br> Că şi miere ţi-am adus.<br> Joacă, joacă Moş Martine,<br> Că-ţi dau miere de albine.<br> Joacă, joacă frumuşel,<br> Si păşeşte mărunţel.<br> Saltă, saltă cât mai sus,<br> Căci stăpânu' ţi s-a dus!<ref name="sendreazbacau"/> | Green leaf of [[Malus|crabapple]],<br> Climb, bear on the stick,<br> Climb higher and higher still,<br> For I brought you honey, too.<br> Dance, dance Old Boy Martin,<br> For I give you the honey of bees.<br> Dance, dance nicely,<br> And take little steps.<br> Jump, jump, higher and higher,<br> For your master has gone away! | |}
==References== {{Reflist|2}} *[[Isabel Fonseca]], ''Bury Me Standing. The Gypsies and Their Journey'', Vintage Departures, New York, 1995. {{ISBN|0-679-73743-X}} *Leo Lucassen, [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/html/cim_pdf461.pdf ''The Power of Definition. Stigmatisation, Minoritisation, and Ethnicity Illustrated by the History of the Gypsies in the Netherlands''], at the [http://adatbank.transindex.ro/ Erdélyi Magyar Adatbank], retrieved June 25, 2007 {{Romani diaspora}} {{Romanian Roma topics}}

{{Refimprove|date=June 2009}} {{Infobox Occupation | name= Vikos doctors | image= | caption= | official_names= <!------------Details-------------------> | type= [[Profession]] | activity_sector= [[Complementary Medicine]] | competencies= traditional knowledge | formation= acquaintance | employment_field= [[traditional medicine]], [[herbal medicine]] | related_occupation= [[physician]] | average_salary= }}
'''Vikos doctors''' were folk [[Traditional healer|healers]] or practical medical practitioners from the [[Greece|Greek]] area of [[Zagori]] in the 18-19th century.
== Etymology == The [[Greek language|Greek]] word [[wikt:ἰατρός|ἰατρός]] (''iatrós'', doctor or healer) is often translated as [[physician]]. Vikos doctors ({{lang-el| βικογιατροί}}) were local doctors practicing a form of [[herbal medicine]] in the 18th and 19th century.
== History ==
The Vikos doctors<ref>Βασίλης Μηνακάκης ‘Ζαγοροχώρια’ (Vasilis Minakakis ‘Zagorochoria’) Explorer, Athens, 2006</ref> hailed from the area of central [[Zagori]] and particularly from the villages of [[Tsepelovo]], [[Fraggades]], [[Papingo]], [[Skamneli]], [[Koukouli, Ioannina|Koukouli]], [[Monodendri, Ioannina|Monodendri]] and [[Kapesovo]]. They used local herbs to heal ailments of people as well as of livestock. These herbs and parts of some other plants were being collected from the [[Vikos|Vikos gorge]], hence the attribution. They were descendants of an ancient craft who in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period attained great fame. Some even served as advisors in the courts of the [[Ottoman Sultan]]s. One named Paschaloglou from [[Kapesovo]] even became a confidente of four [[Ottoman Sultan|Sultans]]: Abdul Hamit I, Suleiman III, Mustafa IV and Mahmut II.
One of the herbs used was the nightshade ''[[Atropa belladonna]]'' for [[cholic]][[spasm]]s. The drug [[atropine]] has been extracted from this plant which is medicinally used for this purpose to our own day. It is also said that two Vikos doctors, Pantazis Exarchou and Zonias, used fungi to treat infected wounds well before [[penicillin]] was discovered by [[Alexander Fleming]]. Other plants with suspected or known medicinal properties were also in their repertory and grow abundantly in the area, among them the lemon balm ''[[Melissa officinalis]]'', St John’s Wort ''[[Hypericum perforatum]]'', absinth ''[[Artemisia absinthium]]'' and the elder bush ''[[Sambucus nigra]]''
== See also == {{portal|Medicine}} * [[Zagori]] * [[Vikos–Aoös National Park]]

revision.text:
[[File:Plastic "WIN" sign.jpg|thumb|Plastic "WIN" sign]]
'''''Whip Inflation Now''''' ('''''WIN''''') was a 1974 attempt to spur a [[grassroots]] movement to combat [[inflation]] in the US, by encouraging personal savings and disciplined spending habits in combination with public measures, urged by [[U.S. President]] [[Gerald Ford]]. The campaign was later described as "one of the biggest government public relations blunders ever".<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/28/AR2006122801002.html|title=Ford's WIN Buttons Remembered|last=CRUTSINGER|first=MARTIN|date=2006-12-28|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-07-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
People who supported the mandatory and voluntary measures were encouraged to wear "WIN" buttons,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-OMNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QHkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7305%2C4218347|title=WIN buttons in high demand|last=Cormier|first=Frank|date=Oct 10, 1974|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> perhaps in hope of evoking in peacetime the kind of solidarity and voluntarism symbolized by the [[V sign#The V for Victory campaign and the victory.2Ffreedom sign|V-campaign]] during [[World War II]].
==Campaign==
Ford had taken office in August 1974 amidst one of the worst economic crises in US history, marked by high unemployment and inflation rising to 12.3% that year following the [[1973 oil crisis]].<ref name=":0" /> As a Republican, Ford favored the WIN campaign's emphasis on addressing the problem through voluntary actions of citizens, instead of price restrictions imposed centrally by a [[big government]] bureaucracy.<ref name=":0" />
The campaign began in earnest with the establishment by the [[93rd United States Congress|93rd Congress]] of the National Commission on Inflation, which Ford closed with an address to the American people, asking them to send him a list of ten inflation-reducing ideas.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HHgsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0PoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7050%2C5980218|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717055527/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HHgsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0PoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7050,5980218|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 17, 2012|title=WIN is losing|date=Dec 20, 1974|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=11 January 2010}} </ref> Ten days later, Ford declared inflation "public enemy number one" before Congress on October 8, 1974, in a speech entitled "Whip Inflation Now", announcing a series of proposals for public and private steps intended to directly affect supply and demand to bring inflation under control. Suggested actions for citizens included [[Carpool|carpooling]], turning down thermostats, and starting their own vegetable gardens.<ref name=":0" />
"WIN" buttons immediately became objects of ridicule; skeptics wore the buttons upside down, explaining that "NIM" stood for "No Immediate Miracles," "Nonstop Inflation Merry-go-round," or "Need Immediate Money."
[[Alan Greenspan]], as the Chairman of the [[Council of Economic Advisors]] during the Ford administration, went along reluctantly with the "Whip Inflation Now" campaign,<ref name=":0" /> but would later recall in his book ''[[The Age of Turbulence]]'' that he was thinking, "This is unbelievably stupid" when the concept was first presented to the [[White House]]. According to historian Yanek Mieczkowski, the public campaign was never meant to be the centerpiece of the anti-inflation program.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=0-8131-2349-6|page=134|url=https://books.google.com/?id=m2JyHO1vNOEC&lpg=PA135&dq=Russell%20Freeburg%20Whip%20inflation%20now&pg=PA134#v=onepage&q=|accessdate=|author=Yanek Mieczkowski|year=2005|publisher=Univ. Press of Kentucky|location=Lexington, Ky.|title=Gerald Ford and the challenges of the 1970s}}</ref>
== Gallery ==
{{cleanup-gallery|date=January 2013}}
<gallery> WIN form.jpg|The WIN form was made available on the day of Ford's ''Whip Inflation Now'' speech. It read "Dear President Ford: I enlist as an inflation fighter and Energy Saver for the duration. I will do the very best I can for America." The form was mailed to the president and the sender would receive a WIN button.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ford Calls for Action on Many Fronts to 'Whip Inflation Now': Sign Up, Get Free WIN Button|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%20Disk3/Watertown%20Times/Watertown%20NY%20Daily%20Times%20%20Oct%201974%20Grayscale/Watertown%20NY%20Daily%20Times%20%20Oct%201974%20Grayscale%20-%200182.pdf|newspaper=[[Watertown Daily Times]]|date=October 9, 1974|agency=Associated Press|pages=7}}</ref> File:"WIN" button.JPG |WIN button </gallery>
<gallery> File:"I can WIN" button.JPG|"I can WIN" button File:"Plant a WIN garden" button.JPG|"Plant a WIN garden" button File:"WIN" bag.jpg|"WIN" bag File:"WIN" button.JPG|"WIN" button File:"WIN" campaign tab.JPG|"WIN" campaign tab File:"WIN" earrings.JPG|"WIN" earrings File:"WIN" football.jpg|"WIN" football File:"WIN" patterned sweater.JPG|"WIN" patterned sweater File:"WIN" stickers.JPG|"WIN" stickers File:"WIN" wristwatch.JPG|"WIN" wristwatch File:"WIN"sign.JPG|"WIN"sign File:WIN needlework picture.JPG|WIN needlework picture File:WIN pin.JPG|WIN pin
File:WIN t-shirt.JPG|WIN T-shirt </gallery>
